qas.question: Where does the Red Book get it's name from?
What is the formal name for a CD?
Do CDs have a two or four channel format?
What format has never been implemented on CDs?
What was the sampling rate for the four-channel sound?
What is the Red Book format for monaural audio?

plausible_answers.text: The logical format of an audio CD

qas.question: What is the official name of the Red Book?
What is the PCM for an MP3 mono sound chanel?

context: <b7_0>The logical format of an audio CD<b7_0/> (officially <a1_0>Compact Disc Digital Audio<a1_0/> or CD-DA) is described in a document produced in <b5_0>1980<b5_0/> by the format's joint creators, Sony and Philips. The document is known colloquially as the Red Book CD-DA after <a0_0>the colour of its cover<a0_0/>. The format is a <a2_0>two-channel<a2_0/> <b6_0><b8_0>16-bit<b8_0/> PCM encoding at a <b4_0>44.1 kHz<b6_0/><b4_0/> sampling rate per channel. <a3_0>Four-channel sound<a3_0/> was to be an allowable option within the Red Book format, but has never been implemented. Monaural audio has no existing standard on a Red Book CD; thus, mono source material is usually presented as two identical channels in a standard Red Book stereo track (i.e., mirrored mono); an MP3 CD, however, can have audio file formats with mono sound.
